questions.question: Every room …………….. been cleaned.
questions.description: We use every before a singular noun. The verb is also singular.

questions.question: Each new day …………………. different.
questions.description: We use each before a singular noun. The verb is also singular.

questions.question: Natives of India …………….. black hair.
questions.description: Here the plural verb ‘have’ agrees with the plural subject ‘natives’.

questions.question: The climate of London …………….. not suit my health.
questions.description: Here the subject is the singular noun ‘climate’ and hence we use the singular verb ‘does’.

questions.question: My sister and I ……………… pleased to accept your invitation.
questions.description: When two singular nouns are connected by ‘and’ the verb should be plural.

questions.question: Each one of these apples …………….. red.
questions.description: We use a singular verb after each one and every one.

questions.question: The whole class ……………… listening to the speech.
questions.description: The expression ‘the whole class’ indicates a single entity and therefore we use a singular verb with it.

questions.question: My sister and my brother ……………… at the party.
questions.description: When two singular nouns are connected by and, they take a plural verb.

questions.question: She and I …………….. having dinner together.
questions.description: When two singular nouns are connected by and, they take a plural verb.

questions.question: Neither red nor green ……………… me.
questions.description: The verb is singular when 'neither' and 'nor' connect two singular nouns.

questions.question: Either Jack or Peter ……………. to clean the room.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with ‘either…or’, the verb agrees with the noun after ‘or’.

questions.question: The President, as well as the Prime Minister, ……………… visiting Moscow.
questions.description: We can connect two subjects with as well as. If the first subject is singular, the verb is also singular.
